column1: Wetumpka (US: ) is a city in and the county seat of Elmore County
column2: Alabama
column3: United States. At the 2010 census the population was 6
column4: 528. In the early 21st century Elmore County became one of the fastest-growing counties in the state. The city is considered part of the Montgomery Metropolitan Area.

column1: Wetumpka identifies as "The City of Natural Beauty". Among the notable landmarks are the Wetumpka crater and the Jasmine Hill Gardens
column2: with a full-sized replica of the Temple of Hera of Olympia
column3: Greece. Historic downtown Wetumpka developed on both sides of the Coosa River. It was near Fort Toulouse
column4: built by French colonists in 1717
column5: when they had claimed this territory for the king.

column1: The placename Wetumpka is derived from the Creek phrase we-wau tum-cau meaning "rumbling waters"
column2: believed to be a description of the sound of the nearby Coosa River at the rapids of the Devil's Staircase. The roar of the rapids reportedly could be heard for miles before the construction in the 20th century of Walter Bouldin Dam and Jordan Dam
column3: when the river was captured as a reservoir behind the dam.After being forced west to Indian Territory (present-day Oklahoma)
column4: by United States soldiers under the Indian Removal Act of 1830
column5: the Muscogee named their major settlement there Wetumka

column1: Wetumpka was long settled by the Muscogee people
column2: whose territory extended through present-day Georgia and Alabama. Their largest towns were on the banks of the Coosa and at its confluence with the Tallapoosa River
column3: at Wetumpka and Talisi (now Tallassee)
column4: respectively.

column1: After moving the 1702 settlement of Mobile to Mobile Bay in 1711
column2: Jean-Baptiste Le Moyne
column3: Sieur de Bienville sent an expedition up the Alabama River to establish a fort in the interior of the colony
column4: known as La Louisiane or New France
column5: to stop the encroachment of British colonists and to foster trade and goodwill with the Creek.

column1: Bienville directed the construction of Fort Toulouse along the Coosa River in 1714
column2: 4 miles (6 km) above the confluence of the Coosa and Tallapoosa rivers and the Creek village of Taskigi. Bienville selected this area as a strategic locale for a fortification.

column1: The French traded at Wetumpka and garrisoned Fort Toulouse until 1763
column2: when they ceded the territory to the British following defeat in the Seven Years' War (known as the French and Indian War in North America). For nearly a quarter century
column3: the British had control of this area. Several Scots and Irish traders
column4: such as McGillivray and Weatherford
column5: were active in the region. They married into the Creek matrilineal aristocracy and later claimed vast land grants. Their descendants became important Creek leaders because of their mothers' status.

column1: After Britain was defeated in the American Revolutionary War
column2: it ceded its territory east of the Mississippi River to the United States in 1783. In 1798 the US made this area part of the Mississippi Territory
column3: after cessions from the states of Georgia and South Carolina. Between 1800 and 1812
column4: European-American pioneers began to arrive
column5: many with enslaved African-American laborers
column6: and encroach on the lands of the Southeast Indian tribes.

column2: there were tensions among the Creek
column3: with young men of the Upper Creek promoting a revival of religion and traditional culture
column4: and the Lower Creek
column5: more influenced by settlement and trade with European Americans in Georgia
column8: the Shawnee chief Tecumseh of the upper Northwest appealed to the Creek to join his Western Confederacy to try to drive out and exterminate the European settlers west of the Appalachians.

column1: When the U.S. declared war on Britain in June 1812
column2: the Upper Creek lost the assistance of the British
column3: but they persisted with war against American settlers in the area. Upon receiving the news of the massacre at Fort Mims
column4: whose refugees included many Lower Creek
column5: American settlers appealed for government help. General Andrew Jackson led a militia with members from Tennessee
column7: and Georgia and attacked the Creek in Alabama. The path the militia traveled became known as "Jackson's Trace".

column1: Jackson's forces won a decisive victory at the Battle of Horseshoe Bend. He moved on to Fort Toulouse
column2: where he directed its repair. During his absence
column3: the site was renamed Fort Jackson in his honor.

column1: Jackson made the fort his headquarters during the War of 1812. The newly created Montgomery County held its courts there. The defeated Creek were forced to sign the Treaty of Fort Jackson (1814)
column2: which ceded to the United States 23
column4: 000 acres (36
column5: 000 sq mi; 93
column6: 000 km2) of Creek lands: much of the remainder of their territory in Georgia and most of central Alabama. After the war
column7: many of Jackson's Tennessee militia returned home
column9: and brought them back to settle near the fort.

column2: mostly from Georgia and the Carolinas
column3: flooded into the fertile land that the Creeks had been forced to give up. With its strategic location at the river confluence
column4: Wetumpka quickly became an important center of agricultural trade. The city was formally incorporated in 1834. Cotton was the commodity crop of the new state of Alabama
column5: with cultivation of short-staple cotton in the upland areas made possible by Eli Whitney's invention of the cotton gin
column6: which reduced the labor of processing. From the scattered fields and large plantations worked by slave labor in the interior
column7: cotton was carted overland to Wetumpka. At the fall line of the Coosa River
column8: the port shipped out cotton bales by steamboats which went downriver to the markets at Mobile for sale.

column1: Wetumpka became a cotton boom town. The new city was divided in half. The part on the eastern bank of the river was commercial
column2: with banks
column3: stores
column4: and hotels
column5: and was located in Coosa County. The western section in Autauga County was residential
column6: with houses and churches laid out on a grid pattern of streets.

column2: the city's population was 1
column3: 200. Harper's Weekly asserted that "Wetumpka
column4: Alabama and Chicago
column5: Illinois are the most promising two cities of the West. The city commissioned a steamboat
column7: to ferry passengers and cotton between Wetumpka and Mobile.

column1: The same forces contributing to Wetumpka's growth were shifting the balance of power within Alabama. A standoff between the farmers of the Tennessee Valley
column2: centered in the former capital of Huntsville
column3: and the old mercantile wealth of Mobile
column4: had resulted in the capital being located for many years at Tuscaloosa. By 1845
column5: the cotton planters in the interior Black Belt had become some of the wealthiest in the country
column6: and power was shifting toward the southern and central part of the state. Both the Black Belt cotton barons and the Mobilians wanted the capital moved.

column2: centrally located capital
column3: accessible by river and by steamboat. The lead contenders were Wetumpka (then straddling old Autauga and Coosa Counties) and the newer city of Montgomery (in Montgomery County)
column4: a few miles south. Neither city had a majority of support; representatives from north Alabama
column5: enraged that the capital was being moved from Tuscaloosa
column6: were indifferent to either site. Just before the vote
column7: Montgomery lured an expensive French chef to the new hotel that had been built to house the state's representatives if Montgomery were selected. The city distributed elegant menus to the statesmen. The promise of luxury swayed the vote
column8: and Montgomery won. That same year
column9: a fire broke out in Wetumpka
column10: burning warehouses and many commercial buildings. The charred bricks were carried downriver to Montgomery to supply the building boom in Alabama's new capital.

column1: Though their civic pride was wounded by losing the capital to Montgomery
column2: Wetumpka's planters and merchants continued to flourish throughout the antebellum period. They promoted a plan to build a lock and dam so that boats would be able to pass above the Fall Line and travel up the Coosa as far as Rome
column3: Georgia. One famous resident was William Lowndes Yancey
column4: a firebrand newspaper editor and statesman who was an influential advocate of states' rights and Southern secession.

column2: representatives from seven Southern states met in Montgomery to form the Confederate government
column3: inaugurating Jefferson Davis as their president on the steps of the Alabama state capitol. The first six states to secede were those whose residents owned the most slaves in the South. The same year saw the majority of Wetumpka's male population going off to war. Wetumpka was never harmed by Federal troops. No Union troops entered the area until early 1865
column4: and they were driven to reach Montgomery to punish the former Confederate capital before the war ended.

column1: Veterans of the war returned to a city and a region whose economy had been completely destroyed. In 1866
column2: a Reconstruction government drew up a new plan of counties for the state
column3: and Elmore County was created out of parts of Coosa
column4: Autauga
column5: and Montgomery counties
column6: with Wetumpka as its county seat. (Rockford was chosen as seat of the "new" Coosa County.)

column2: the worst flood in city history inundated the west bank and most of downtown. The bridge connecting the city's two halves was washed away
column3: and more than a year passed before it was replaced.

The first paved road linking Wetumpka with Montgomery was completed in 1924. Montgomery continued to grow during the two World Wars because of military spending in the region and the growth of the state government. By the 1950s
column2: the ubiquity of the automobile allowed Wetumpka's residents to commute daily to Montgomery for work.

column1: Wetumpka is located southwest of the center of Elmore County at 32°32′27″N 86°12′28″W (32.540972
column3: and sits on both sides of the Coosa River 5 miles (8 km) northeast of its confluence with the Tallapoosa River
column4: where they merge to become the Alabama River.

column1: The city is situated astride the Fall Line
column2: where the Appalachian foothills give way to the flat Gulf Coastal Plain.

column1: The city is located along many major US and state routes
column2: notably U.S. Route 231
column3: which runs east of downtown
column4: leading north 28 mi (45 km) to Rockford and south 18 mi (29 km) to downtown Montgomery. Alabama State Route 14 runs west to east through the downtown area
column5: leading east 22 mi (35 km) to Tallassee and southwest 17 mi (27 km) to Prattville. Other state highways that run through the city include Alabama State Route 9 and Alabama State Route 170.

column1: Downtown Wetumpka covers two city blocks
column2: and is bordered on the northwest by the Coosa River. The Bibb Graves Bridge crosses the river here
column3: and is the city's most recognizable landmark. Directly across the bridge are the city's three antebellum churches
column4: the First Methodist
column5: First Presbyterian

column3: and recreation ==

column1: Three major films have been filmed on location in downtown Wetumpka.
Wetumpka is the home of "Alabama's greatest natural disaster". A meteorite
column2: estimated to be 1
column3: 000 feet (300 m) wide
column4: hit the area about 80 million years ago. The hills just east of downtown showcase the eroded remains of a 5-mile-wide (8 km) impact crater that was blasted into the bedrock
column5: with the area labeled the Wetumpka crater or astrobleme ("star-wound") for the concentric rings of fractures and zones of shattered rock that can be found beneath the surface. In 2002
column6: Auburn University researchers published evidence and established the site as an internationally recognized impact crater.

column1: This outdoor museum was built in the 1930s on the estate of the Fitzpatrick family
column2: who spent many years in Greece collecting replicas of ancient statuary to adorn their formal gardens at Jasmine Hill. Today the gardens are run as a non-profit foundation dedicated to promoting the arts and Greek culture. Frequently the site of local weddings
column3: its attractions include a full-sized replica of the Temple of Hera at Olympia.

column1: Wetumpka and the Coosa River annually play host to the Coosa River Challenge
column2: which began in 2003 and regularly draws 150 to 200 participants. The race
column3: a modified triathlon
column4: starts at the Swayback Bridge Trail with a cross country run
column5: a mountain bike leg
column6: and paddling on the Coosa River to finish at Goldstar Park in downtown Wetumpka.

column1: The Swayback Bridge Trail is home to the annual mountain bike race
column2: "Attack on Swayback".

column1: Wetumpka is popular with white water sports enthusiasts
column2: attracting paddlers from all over the country. The city hosts the annual Coosa River Whitewater Festival
column3: and was the site of the 2005 U.S. Freestyle Kayaking Nationals. The Coosa River Paddling Club has constructed Corn Creek Park
column4: which offers public access to the river
column5: along with nature and walking trails.

column1: Christmas on the Coosa is an annual series of events held in during the month of December. The event location is the Bibb Graves Memorial Bridge. The main event is the fireworks display and boat show held on the Coosa River. Observers watch from the Bibb Graves Memorial Bridge as a parade of boats decorated with Christmas lights float down the river under the bridge as fireworks go off. This is a unique experience due to the glow of fireworks illuminating the night sky as well as the placid river surface. A host of events proceeds the river show such as Miss Christmas on the Coosa Pageant
column2: Pictures with Santa
column3: tree lighting
column4: and other events centralized around the city's Gold State Park.

column1: The United States Postal Service operates the Wetumpka Post Office.The Julia Tutwiler Prison for Women of the Alabama Department of Corrections is in Wetumpka. The prison houses Alabama's female death row. Wetumpka was previously the site of the Wetumpka State Penitentiary.
